title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act may be cited as the "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" and establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. States without a current high-risk pool must establish one to meet the requirement. As of the date of enactment, States must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a high-risk pool to meet requirements. If a State already operates a high-risk pool, it will not be considered as such after January 1, 2015. States must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a high-risk pool to meet requirements. If a State already operates a high-risk pool, it will not be considered as such after January 1, 2015. The State may use premium assessment funds to transition from a high-risk pool to a qualified State reinsurance program if the pool is a qualifying State high-risk pool. If the program or pool is in strong fiscal health, as determined by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and approved by the State Insurance Commissioner, the requirement shall be deemed met. A qualified State reinsurance program is defined as a program under this section. A qualified State reinsurance program provides reinsurance for health insurance coverage in the small group market. It can operate on a prospective or retrospective basis and protect insurers against annual aggregate spending and individual catastrophic costs. The program is deemed a qualified high-risk pool for HIPAA requirements. A qualifying State high risk pool must offer at least two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account. It must have stable funding, eliminate waiting lists, cover individuals waiting for Medicare eligibility, and limit premiums. The qualifying State high risk pool must limit premiums to 150 percent of the average standard risk rates, provide education and outreach, cover preventive services and disease management, and only allow citizens and nationals of the United States to participate. As a condition for receiving funds, States must certify that applicants for coverage in high-risk pools provide citizenship documentation. The Secretary will maintain records to verify citizenship once. Starting January 1, 2015, high-risk pools must meet specific criteria to qualify under the Public Health Service Act. Waivers may be granted for new programs. The Secretary may waive requirements for State reinsurance programs and high-risk pools. Funding of $25 billion is appropriated for fiscal years 2015-2024. Definitions for health insurance coverage and issuer are provided. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" is defined under the Public Health Service Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined by considering premium rates, using actuarial techniques, and reflecting anticipated claims and expenses. The term "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia.
